You can find cheaper table games here but it's more smokier in here than in other casinos.  We came in here to see if it had changed but it still looks and feels like it did when it opened.

We changed our reservations from another hotel locally because I had some comps available at the New York New York. What a great deal. I payed $47 total for 4 nights in the players suite. I had already earned $150 in free play and they gave me $250 resort credit so this was a super deal. 

The room was clean and ready by 1pm and they let me check in. The room is nice but not super fancy. 

The not so good things. The tv remote did not have batteries so had to call maintenance. The tub drained very slowly and I had to remove the drain stopper. The pillows were super lumpy and in my opinion worn out. That's about it. Otherwise a decent hotel and a great deal so don't take this as a complaint, just an honest review. I would stay here again without hesitation. 

They have a really cool dueling piano show in their piano bar. It's a small cover to get in, just a few bucks but the dueling piano players are awesome. They also have very affordable snack restaurants and nothing too fancy.

I've stayed here a few times now and I really enjoy the scene at this place. Its a place for the younger crowd to hang out in. 

The casino is clean and staff is really cool. Won big at this place. Had great killer margaritas and food was delicious.

The rooms both times I stayed here had great views! Love this place.

One of the lamer places you can go to on the Strip, with a silly faux New York interior with a number of not-so-good food options. It's small, too, so even if the cheap attempt at capturing NYC doesn't make you roll your eyes, your time going around it will probably not be plentiful. Just not a place worth spending time at.

We stayed at New York, New York for a long weekend & loved it!  The atmosphere, the rooms, the restaurants, the clubs... everything was great!  

Upon arriving my husband checked us in & he was upgraded because he is active duty military.  We also went to the Irish Bar & Coyote Ugly (both inside of NY NY) where we both got in free, no cover, because of being military. 

Also, we were able to eat right in NY NY every night because of all the great restaurant choices.  We had pizza from the NY Pizzeria, it was good & not over-priced.  The deli style restaurant they have there is the absolute best sandwich I have ever had in my life!  Again, not over-priced espcially considering you are in Las Vegas.  

The last night we went to see the show Zumanity at NY NY (where they also gave an incredible military discount for tickets) & ate dinner at the Mexican restaurant, Gonzalez Y Gonzalez.  It is semi-expensive for mexican food but worth every penny!  We ordered a crab guacamole where they have everything cut fresh & mix it right at your table.  The margaritas are to die for as well!  

The only down fall is, of course the additional resort fees you pay like any other hotel on the strip.  Other than losing some money at the craps tables... this was our favorite trip to Vegas!!!

Is it bad that I loved the New York- New York? After all, I am from the big apple. Neeew Yooooork, concrete jungle where dreams are made of there's nothing you can't do!

I took a walk through on the way to the Roller Coaster. The casino was very fun themed and full of busy bright lights, a lot like the city I love. Even the guys handing out flyers, and discount books added the New York flavor to the hotel\/ casino. There were pretzel shops, pizza shops, ice cream stores and a coyote ugly to definitely make you feel like you're in the heart of New York. 

I definitely wonder how it would be to stay at the hotel and constantly run into that type of traffic.

Don't miss the coaster ride if your staying on the strip and get to New York New York. Irish pub was great with live music from a one man band, who just wailed away on his sax, accompanied by prerecorded background tracks. That was perfect as the venue would have been cramped with even a small band of 4 or 5. As it was, everyone was able to see and enjoy his superb playing in comfort. The Broadway Celebration show was enjoyable and the performers worked very hard to make sure the audience was entertained. They worked SO hard and left it all on stage. Went with my son and daughter in law and we all enjoyed it. Also, if you've got a sweet tooth like me, you can get your Krispy Kreme doughnut fix right on the casino floor. Yum!

lame. 
i walked in a pseudo-NY themed casino. i really thought a nostalgic nerve would hit me- but it didn't. everything from the fake-ass Greenwich Village to Coney Island- are you sh*ttin' me?!?! anyway, it's not totally a slumped up joint- it has it's fine points, but i actually LIVE in NYC- so i was simply not amused. 

the casino itself is small and non-engaging. the pizza joints and delicatessens are merely imitations and not the same experience. but whatevs... if you want to play imaginary NYC in your mind as you're vacationing in Vegas- go right ahead.

Great hotel! Should have planned ahead better tho, flew into town early morning and had no idea we couldn't check in until 3pm. We were, however, able to check our luggage in so at least we didn't have to drag that everywhere with us. That being said, once we finally got upstairs to our room, it was very nice and comfortable. The bed was heavenly. The roller coaster track was right outside our window but we didn't catch any noise from it. And maybe it's silly but I loved that there was a hair dryer in the bathroom lol. The statue of liberty made out of candy was awesome! Also lots of great places to eat inside the casino. Our favorite was Nine Fine Irishmen, which I'll write a separate review for, and we had breakfast twice at America the Beautiful, also inside the casino, and it was great. Expensive, but food and service was good and lots of cool decorations on the ceiling and walls. I should note that breakfast for two of us, tip included, was over 50$.

New York New York never sent a post-stay survey, so I'm posting here what I would've told them had they bothered to ask. I won't rate this hotel on the gaudy exterior or tacky interior since it's all par for Vegas. And I won't get into the general ambiance, but suffice to say it is, as you'd expect, a place for those with dying dreams. You will love NYNY if you like your air stuffy, smoke-filled, and heavy with the desperation of hundreds of strangers forcing themselves to have some approximation of so-called fun.

So none of that is why I'm giving one star to this supposedly classy Vegas mainstay. Rather, NYNY's main downfall is its housekeeping department. The front desk kicked things off by checking me into a room that was listed in their computer as cleaned, but had never actually been touched (unmade beds, trash can full of empty perfume bottles, etc). When I called down to ask to change rooms to one that'd been cleaned sometime within the last 72 hours, no one ever picked up the phone.

A trip downstairs on NYNY's hilariously overworked and insufficient elevators resulted in--to their credit--a modest room upgrade (a clean one at that). The next day I was gone from roughly 12-9pm, and despite no 'Do Not Disturb' sign, nobody came by. So at 9pm I asked that it be cleaned while we were at dinner. "No problem, sir." Would you be surprised to hear that 2.5 hours later it still hadn't been touched? At this point I called it a night and asked for the front desk to let me know what super secret code you need to whisper in order to get service. 

The next day, against all odds, housekeeping stopped by.

But the day after that, they were back to their usual ways: no one came at all the entire day. (Again despite no sign on the door and nobody being there all day.)

I won't even get into the quality of service once staff do actually clean: empty toiletries left scattered around, the unwanted hairs from previous guests \/ current staff, etc. You will also enjoy the pleasures of room service carts lining the hallways because nobody ever thinks to come pick them up. Never been in a hotel where you can pass somebody's room in the morning, see their food cart outside their door, and then see that same damn cart still there when you pass by again at night. 

All that to say: if you want to pay 2016 Vegas prices to experience something like a no-star hourly motel from 1990s New York City, then this past-its-prime 1c slot machine of a hotel is probably perfect for you. (Just make sure you check out by 11am or these price-gougers will assess yet another fee for the honor of a slightly later checkout.)

P.S. - none of this is actually meant to knock the housekeeping staff themselves. This kind of poor service is indicative of management's issues: not enough hiring, not enough training, not enough clear processes, not enough attention to detail. God help the poor staff who have to work in this kind of place for almost assuredly awful wages.

Definitely a solid stay in the Vegas area if you're looking for a resort that has proper living quarters while in town. This hotel is geared towards an older crowd as they don't feature any pool or night clubs.

NY NY is home to a cirque du soleil production- Zumanity which is focused for an 18+ club. Think of it as an acrobatic burlesque show!

Of course you'll find their mini neighborhood featuring staple New York foods like deli shops, NY style pizza, and hot dogs.

They offer a pool and a few amenities. Overall for the price you'll be pleased with your stay.

Besides the pretty cool roller coaster on top of the hotel, they really have nothing good going for them. 

The hotel conceirge was horribly and took forever to locate my room reservation and she kept on question my other guest what was their sur-name to check if it was under their name(NO BIOTCH! IT'S UNDERSTAND MY NAME!!!), dealers paid no attention to cards what so ever!!!! Just strictly deal the cards and pay and take as their are taught and another dealer really pissed me off when she asked I.Ded me and I wasn't even playing on the table!!!!!!! However she did I.D. everyone on the table also a 50+ years old woman! 

The hotel room smelled like shit since we were stuck with a smoking room because my room was complimentary that was all they had for me, BULLSHIT! I don't even know why I'm complaining about the room since I am not even staying there! HAHAHA But it's an extra room for me buddy

Overall, I enjoyed my stay at the NYNY.

The good:
- NYC theme is cute, and pretty well executed
- Room was a good size, beds were comfy, everything was clean
- Casino floor is sprawling, with lots of food\/drink options
- Some fun penny slots for the gambling n00bs (my favorite being The Wizard of Oz - Big Event!)
- Decent price

The bad:
- On the far end of the strip, so you'll be truckin' your butt across the desert if you want to hit up other spots
- While I'm sure its intentional, the layout can be confusing - we got lost almost every time we were trying to find our elevator

I'd stay here again :)

First time staying here. Stayed on the 17th floor and it was a really great size. Big living room area with a dining room and a nice sized room with a jacuzzi tub in it near the windows and also a bathroom with a vanity and a regular shower on the other side of the room. It was good prized and perfect for my little weekend getaway. The drinks were good. Pizza downstairs was great. The vibe was relaxed and the people there were real cool and dressed casual. The casino is okay. They have an pretty fun arcade and a roller coaster as well. The parking is kind of funny and out of the way but other than that, I enjoyed my stay here. Rooms were clean and housekeeping was on point. Ordered room service(it's 24hours) and it was pretty good

this is not NYC, and if you're too cheap to actually go to NYC, then please do not go here. This is NOT a replica of NYC, hell the buildings are off and don't look right, seriously wtf? 

Get on the roller coaster if you want. I think its being held together by duct tape and barbed wire. I'm surprised they didn't put king kong in there as well.

but hey you can buy 12 keychains for 10 dollars! that's a deal right there! then again why would you need 12 keychains? Who knows.

Seeing them sell I love ny t shirts and yankee stuff is totally weird. seeing them sell NYPD and FDNY stuff there is beyond weird, considering half of it isn't "authentic" or real or even endorsed or by the organizations, even though they put on a sticker or sign stating that it is. There's a sucker born every minute. I guess in here its more often than that.

Coyote Ugly is located in here. Totally loud and overrated.

Went to Las Vegas for the first time recently, and we stayed part of the week at Paris and the other few days at New York, New York. We ended up getting a pretty good deal at NYNY, which ended up being $50 less per night than Paris, and we liked it a whole lot more! 

I would say that the lobby\/casino area of NYNY isn't as cutesy or fancy as the other hotels we stayed in\/visited, but the rooms definitely make up for this fact! Not super big, but very clean and seemed to have been recently updated with modern furniture and bedding. The beds were SO comfortable...it felt like I was sleeping on a cloud. I seriously did not want to leave. I can't wait to stay there again, just because of those BEDS! 

And the bathroom in our room was gorgeous. Mind you, we only got the most basic room offered, and it was covered in beautiful floor-to-ceiling granite tiles. And the tub was actually BIG. Normally a standard hotel tub is barely big enough to fit your left leg in, never mind your whole body. But I was able to have a perfectly good soak in my NYNY tub, and I loved it!

After visiting quite a few different hotels on the strip, and also staying at the Paris, I can without a doubt say that NYNY will be our first choice when we come back next year! Great prices, perfect rooms, and accessible to the highway. I couldn't have been happier with our stay!

My experience at this hotel was quite pleasant, Staff was excellent but hotel could use a touch up in the rooms and public restrooms,had some peeling wallpaper in the bathroom and the restrooms in the casino look worn and unkept. Good selections of places to eat and shop, kids loved the arcade. Wifi was poor most of the time not working therefore missed out on redemption of myvegas points for perks. Would stay again but only if Wifi improved.

Rooms are very clean and staff was very friendly. they need to get rid of Nathan's Hotdogs because it might actually be ass on a bun. Most machines paid out. Only complaint about the room is that i didn't have a mini fridge.

When I think of New York City itself, I think big!  There's nothing about the city is small: big buildings, big monuments, big personalities, etcs.  So naturally I thought of the same of New York New York casino and hotel in Las Vegas.

I remember that I was in awe when NY NY first opened.  The casino did a pretty good job encompassing exterior decor that gave it the feel of New York City.  I appreciated the replicas of the Brooklyn Bridge, the Statue of Liberty, the skyline, and ferry boats.  That was years ago when I was just visiting the casino.

Recently I had the opportunity to stay there for a couple of nights.  The lobby itself was pretty spectacular with its' New York themes, decorations, and old photographs.  Strolling through its' food court gave me that New York feel.  Pretty cool so far.

The moment of truth was going into my room.  Unfortunately that was where the New York feel ended.  The room itself was not bad: comfy queen sized beds, alot of closet and drawer spaces, and an overall nice set up.  What really surprised me was the room was kind of plain and somewhat bland.  No splash of vibrant colors or anything.  The bathroom was quite small and also bland.  No only that but the amenities were very minimal: one small bottle of shampoo, one small bottle of conditioner, one small tube of lotion, and one small bar of soap.  Plus there's no in-room coffee maker to make yourself a cup of coffee or tea.  For a hotel\/casino in suchy close proximity of MGM, Excalibur, and Monte Carlo, one would think NY NY would be equally comparable.

The casino is not smoke-free but you can request a non-smoking room.  However the lingering smoke was everywhere even if you're on a non-smoking floor.

NY NY is affordable during the beginning of the week with the automatic $15\/day room fee tacked on.  Aside from room WiFi, the fee covers amenities that hardly anybody uses but I suspect they're added on at other big named casinos along the Strip.  The location of NY NY was ideal.  The parking situation was rather odd: you have to stop at the entrance for an employee to get a really good look at you (roll down window completely) before you can proceed.  I don't know what that person was looking for but none of the other casinos I've visited had that.  One of them was rather rude.

Overall NY NY was good but not spectacular.  Aside from the decor and NY theme, nothing about it really stood out.  I would prefer staying at other places.

This is one of the most exciting hotels on the strip. The staff is very friendly. The linens and room very clean. The bed was very comfortable, but could use 2 more pillows of which were very nice. The jacuzzi in our room was relaxing. With room service, I found it hard to want to leave the room. If you do leave the room the mock up of NYC streets are so lovely without the awful humidity in NYC. The food and dessert selections are so varied every selective eater can be satisfied. The roller coaster is a deal. Buy 1 Get 1 for guests. I had no idea there was a loop! 
Beautiful views. Vegas is back and the recession is gone, with that resort fees and parking fees are back and so too are higher food and room rates.

really liked the floor of the casino.  Sportsbook is decent, seemed like they had better\/more realistic lines than a couple other places.  Thought the "streets of new york" or whatever, was pretty cheesy, even if they did have a great little deli.  Wouldn't doubt they have a decent pizza their either. 
If you're with your family, there's a cool little arcade.  Don't go on the roller coaster, you have a pretty good chance of getting whiplash.

It was my honey's bday and surprised him with a Vegas adventure. I booked with NYNY because the location was primo and the price was not as ludicrous in comparison to the Wynn, Venetian, etc. for Memorial Day weekend. We arrived in Vegas at 3pm on Friday. We were afraid there would be a slew of people at check-in for the holidays. Luckily, there was no line, and the lovely desk lady quickly checked us in, upgraded us to a nicer room with a view for $15 extra, provided us info on things to do around the place, and gave us coupons for 2 complimentary drinks and shopping discounts around the NYNY hotel.

We went up to the rooms. OK. They aren't Wynn quality or anything like that. But the place was clean, spacious enough, and had all the basic amenities you need (AND free water! A must in Vegas!). It did not come with a mini fridge though, so forget about bringing back food. AND, I did notice the cable channels SUCKED. Very little channels. The NYNY commercials were cheesy and adult oriented. More class please! What if kids were flicking through the channels???

Anyhoo. Aside from that, we had free access to the pool and fitness center. I didn't swim in the pool, but it looked big and nice. I did go to the fitness center. It had everything you needed to get a good workout. Cardio machines, free weights, weight machines, mats, balls, etc. It also came with additional free amenities like bottled water, headphones, and the cardio machines came with your own TV. The views were nice because it overlooked the pool. I really enjoyed that part of the hotel. Additionally, for an extra $10, hotel guests can get get access to the spa amenities such as: jacuzzi, steam room, treats, etc.

Overall, I think the stay was pretty nice. It wasn't a 5-star experience, but the atmosphere, freebies, and price made it a good 4 star rating.

Where's Security? We ate 3 different times in the food area of the hotel within 48 hours. Each and EVERY time the SAME homeless guy came up to us to panhandle. Is he an employee?!  It's uncomfortable being harassed inside the hotel. It was literally more comfortable in the food court across the street. At least you can eat in peace there.

---REVISED 2\/9\/2017---
All MLIFE hotels including NYNY now charge for parking. It's usually about $8. If you are mlife pearl level, self-parking (but not valet) is free (use your players card when you enter and exit the parking lot). Gold level or higher gets you free self-parking *and* free valet parking.

The resort fee is now $33.60 per night at NYNY.

--- ORIGINAL 6\/2\/2015 REVIEW ---
I've stayed here a few times now, most recently in late May 2015. It's centrally located on the strip. There are connecting walkways to the Excalibur, Luxor and Mandalay Bay.

The check-in process was fine, and the staff was friendly and accommodating.
The check-out process was simple. You can do it in a number of ways.. via the television, in-person, or via internet.

Wi-fi "everywhere" (in the hotel) and fitness center use are included in the resort fee ([resort fee amount deleted by user- see update]). I think I clocked about 5M download speed on the wi-fi. The resort fee also includes: local and 800 calls, boarding pass printing, notary, 2-for-1 roller coaster passes, faxing (five page limit) and daily newspaper.

Shower, faucet, and lavatory worked fine. Water pressure in the shower was great, and the shower head had a comfortable spray pattern.

[Parking pricing comment deleted by user - see update]. If you self-park in the right place, the exit from the parking structure is right next to the Century Tower elevators.

During the weekdays, craps has table limits as low as $10, with the typical 3\/4\/5x odds.

The Big Apple.

Meh.  As far as hotels on the strip go, you've seen one you've seen them all.  Literally and figuratively...at least for the most part.  I mean, you have outliers like The Wynn but places like that are exceptions to the mediocre rule.  I'm not sure what we paid for the room, but there were 4 guys sharing it.  So, in the end it came out relatively cheap.  And since we were in Vegas for a friend's bachelor party weekend extravaganza, lounging in the room would be kept to a minimum.  You know how it goes.

So, it was supposed to be a a non-smoking room, but when we walked in, it smelled like a wet ashtray.  But, I guess that's to be expected.  The room was a double and had two good sized queen beds with pretty comfortable mattresses.  Decor was run-of-the-mill Las Vegas blah and the bathroom was good sized and clean.  Nothing too spectacular, but it served it's purpose well: to sleep 4 inebriated and semi-coherent men comfortably.

The casino itself was like the room.  Again, nothing too spectacular.  And like every other casino, it served it's purpose well:  To get you drunk while you gamble away your money and make the worst decisions possible.  

And while we didn't see any of the hotel shows, word on the street is, Zumanity is Cirque du Soleil with tits.  So, if you're into that, then check it out.    If not, then you can ride the roller coaster or throw more money away at the diner called America....more on that shit hole later.

All in all, NYNY is, well, a hotel, on the Las Vegas strip.  Nothing more, nothing less.

New York, New York the Las Vegas Casino has a little bit of nothing and a lot of everything. Roller coasters, a bit of a crazy interior décor theme, a few large centrally located bathrooms and sprawling elevators. It's a pretty unique place in comparison to all the other hotels on the strip. The rooms are basic, and a little dated, but they are quiet and the pool is nice, but not spacious enough. The rates are good, but the towels suck and they often are out of many amenities, I think they are a bit under stocked as I've yet to get a fridge or humidifier even with advanced request. I'll give them one thing, their AC gets cold, just the way I like it. They have no real restaurants, but rather café's and shops, not soo much a shopping area, but just boutiques while you're on the way out. The beds are what you pay for, the sheets were clean, but thin and well used, not somewhere I'd visit again. ROK is ok, but is more of an updated club version of Coyote Ugly bar. Las Vegas has come a long way since NYNY was a relevant player in the Vegas hotel game. 2nd best on that corner, but that's not saying much when Excalibur and Tropicana are your competition behind MGM.

This review is for the casino and gift shops :).

I think this casino is the most "family" friendly compared to other ones on the strip. The Arcade area by the Roller Coaster entrance was pretty impressive for kids all ages (including me). Too bad I'm such a chicken, I didn't ride the roller coaster. 

The casino is just like any other casinos in Las Vegas. I have to say, I love the gift shops merchandise. They have cool t-shirts compared to other casinos. Who doesn't love a t-shirt with New York New York writing on it? On top of that, the t-shirt has Ed Hardy feels to it...of course you will love to get one (now I'm being sarcastic). 

In all seriousness, I will consider to stay at New York New York for my next visit. :).

I stayed at New York New York for a weekend while in Vegas. When I checked in I asked for a good room and was not disappointed. The very nice check in clerk set me up with a corner room which provided views almost 180 degrees around. Awesome. 

After we checked in our bathroom sink was clogged and not working. We went back to the front desk to tell them and no less than 2 hours later it was unclogged and working. No big deal, and they fixed in quickly. 

I love the restaurants at NY NY and the casino area. There is easy access to other casinos with the bridges. 

The pool however is not so great, I have seen larger pools at airport hotels. Tip if you get a lower floor you might have to deal with the sound of the roller coaster, which I heard complaints about. So when you check in ask to be put away from the roller coasters. 

Another reason why NY NY didn't get 5 stars is that the elevators are slow and there are only two of them to get to some of the rooms. So had to wait sometimes up to 5 minutes just to get upstairs. 

But overall this is a great place to stay for not alot of money. Employees are nice, the rooms are nice, the casino is nice so this place is all around nice.

Surprisingly a good hotel! Not sure I would pay retail price to stay here, but when booking via priceline and getting 30-40% off, heck yeah!!

Great place, with lots of great restaurants, and centrally located!

Have you had an experience having a "home" away from home? Well, New York New York Hotel has been the place until 2017 St. Patrick's weekend, March 16th-19th, for my reservations. It's not cheap, but it had been worth it for many, many years until now. 

First, I'd like to compliment two employees, they should get 5 stars. However, this review is for my experience with 1 employee from Housekeeping that ruined it ALL. The good: 
First, Gale from Customer Service for taking my request regarding my room reservations and answering questions regarding my stay. She's very kind, patient, and willing to help. Secondly, the Asian lady from housekeeping, who attempted to clean my room on Saturday, March 18th in New Yorker Towers. She was very diligent and accommodating when I only wanted to take my trash out of my room. She even tried to refuse the tip I gave her just because I happily declined  to have her cleaned my room. 

The BAD:
Now the reason why I only wanted to take my trash out on Saturday was because of my awful experience from housekeeping last Friday, March 17th.  I had left $23 tip on the table for MARIA M.-name tag (female, Hispanic, 5' 02 or 5' 03", between the ages of 45-55 yrs old-yep, I remember details from any good\/bad encounter, especially bad) from housekeeping for cleaning my room later on that day. I was on my way out of my room between 9:45-11:00 am to go somewhere when I wanted to purchase a drink from the vending machine. I knew the vending machines accept $10, 5, even ones. The 3-one-dollar bills I had left for Maria with the $20 were kind of crumpled and couldn't use it in the vending machine. 

So I stepped out of my room, and saw the cleaning cart almost next door, could have been Room 2859, and said hello to see if anyone was in the room. Maria came out and I asked her if she had any change for $10. She said no at first, and then she said yes. She then asked me if I wanted my room cleaned while taking the $10 from my hand and reaching into her apron or one of the pockets. I replied yes to her question then she handed me 5 $1-dollar-bills back. I glanced back in her eyes with a puzzled look and said I can take 2 $5s or a $5 and 5-$1s. She then looked at me and said, "I clean your room, $5 for me, and $5 for you."  All I could do at that time was thanked her, kept my 5-$1s and went back in my room, sat down, tried to process what just happened and imagining what would she have done to my toothbrush if I didn't let her keep the $5. I took the $20 dollars back and left the $3 on the table. (Sorry, Maria. You could have had $23 tip, but you made me cringe in the most uncomfortable way). 

I've never experienced anything so forward in my life, especially having celebrated St. Patrick's in NY NY Hotel for the last 14 years, either with my friends, family, or boyfriend-thanks to RiRá the house band at Nine Fine Irishmen for playing such great music, who is an amazing group of collectively talented and truly kind at heart musicians. 

Now, St. Patrick's in 2018 might be a different story. I would definitely stay somewhere else just to avoid certain housekeepers or hustlers in New York New York Hotel. I don't want to ruin my yearly tradition by experiencing something unpleasant from this hotel. Undoubtedly, bar none, worst experience ever from housekeeping. 


p.s. 
I bought a new toothbrush.
The draft beer bar on the upper level next to Coyote Ugly, is a really great draft beer bar. Twenty drafts, many are IPA's and they have video blackjack on the M Life card. All is good.

I have stayed at this hotel, Excalibur, Stratosphere, MGM Grand and Mandarin Oriental on my trips to Vegas. This is not a bad hotel but theres nothing that stands out here. 

Pros: 

*Location location location. 
Close to MGM, Excalibur, Ceasars and a lot of other hotels on the strip. 
*Free parking garage (as most hotels on the strip) 
*Lots of restaurant choices to choose from.
 My favorite? Gallaghers for the steak. 
*Rooms are large and modern. Feels like its been recenty remodeled
*Starbucks opened at 05:30 in the morning wich is great for the jetlagged europeans 
like myself. 

Cons:

*While not an expensive hotel i think its a little to pricey for what you get. 
*The pool area. Small and with poolbar that fits it and theres not a lot of people there. 
It also gets shady pretty early in the afternoon. 

Conclusion? This is an "ok" hotel with fair pricing and lots of restaurants that has a good location on the strip. As the Excalibur is cheaper, has the same quality of rooms and a lot better pool area i would stay there instead. Yes the lobby\/casinopart of Excalibur feels really old and dated but as im not a gambler who spends a lot of time there, i dont care. 

And if moneys not an issue? Mandarin Oriental all the way in Vegas where the service and ambiance is unmatched.

NYNY was....OK....just ok.  I understand that everyone smokes at the casino's. I get it. But to sleep in a room where is seems that there is someone smoking in the room when there isn't was annoying. I think they need to check the ventilation of this place. After a few nights, the smoke that seems to be dubbed into the room was too much for me. 

I will give them credit for moving us into another room when we had a group of partiers next to us all night. I sound like an old lady but I am not. When you figure in the time change of 3 hours and go to be at 3a.m., I was up for almost 24 hours. The walls were so thin, it was as if the people in the room next to me were in my face yelling. I had to sleep a few hours!! 

So the last complaint I have is, and it may sound petty but I was served a bill at check out, for  the "phone". You are charged $4 a day, every day for the phone in your room even if you don't use it. Why? They just took my cabfare home.

===========================
RJR - ISSUE #11 - Special Edition
===========================

"LOCATION! LOCATION! LOCATION!"

This hotel is on my favorite end of the Las Vegas Strip...but best of all it's in walking distance and centralized between the likes of the Bellagio, Monte Carlo, MGM Grand, Luxor, and Manadalay Bay. Location is one of the reasons why I highly favor this hotel.

Now we're not talking Waldorf-Astoria Hotel so don't expect Park Avenue perks when it comes to staying here.  But for Las Vegas glitz and glam its a nice fascade of New York Imagery.
http:\/\/ltierney.demon.co.uk\/webimages\/galleries\/12\/fullsize\/IMG_4394.JPG

Now...I'm not much on gambling....

But when I am in sin city... I do like to check out the glitz , a show or two, people watch among the tourist from all over the world, check out the local eats...and most of all...relax when I want to get away from the crowds...

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Which is why we like to stay at one NY-NY's Spa deluxe Rooms.
http:\/\/www.nynyhotelcasino.com\/images\/hotel\/center_hotel_spa.jpg

Rates From: $155 a night

A comfortable pad with 400-500 square feet...one king-size bed, sitting area and large clover-shape spa tub thoughtfully positioned in the corner of the bedroom.  The bathroom is very roomy with an over-size shower and vanity.   And there's more than enough space to unload your luggage & lay out all your gear for your Vegas stay.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Living the Vegas life with your own spa in your room is the way to go!  And keep in mind I do believe the Luxor and Caesar's offer similar Spa Deluxe rooms.

I highly recommend!


*SPECIAL BONUS FEATURES*

-  Don't forget to check out there promotions board from time to time for package deals:
http:\/\/www.nynyhotelcasino.com\/promotions\/ 

- Check out - Coyote Ugly - Where hot female bartenders will entertain you with their cool artistic pouring techniques.
http:\/\/www.coyoteuglysaloon.com\/vegas\/coyotes.html

Good location. Clean rooms. Check in took at least an hour.. Didn't eat inside hotel cuz everything closed around 10 or 11pm... Nice to have a rollercoaster outside your window..staff was very friendly

The casino it'self was just like any other casino in Vegas.  It was clean, large variety of games.  I'm happy with that.  I am THRILLED with the selections of food options at NY NY.  You name it and it's there.  Love everything I had to eat.  The hotel was extreamly clean and the bed was one of the most comfortable beds I have ever slept in.  NY NY will be where I stay in vegas from now on.  Loved It!!  Just wish all the restaurants were open 24\/7.

Omigod I LOOOOOVE this casino!  It's really easy to get lost.  I will say that, I was looking for a machine by the escalators and could not find it and you'd think with a landmark like "escalator" that would not be a problem.  

It made me feel like I was home!  The layout of the "streets" was great and the BEST part was the high ceilings studded with "stars" that did not make me feel claustrophobic or like the casino man was trying to confuse me and keep me there forever and ever.  

It helped that they had the monopoly machine.  Watching that machine is like watching coffee.  If you can imagine the non-boring version of that.  I feel like if I explain this comparison further, it's just going to get weird and confusing.  Anyway, I love that machine, AND I love the wheel of fortune machines that are located by the car that I would never want to win because who wants to win a stupid four door white car and then have to pay taxes on it?  Not I, said the fly.  

Yeah, I think the ceilings make this casino great.  That and the decor.  And the Brooklyn Bridge.  I was afraid to try the bagels, because then it would have ruined my fantasy about being back on the East Coast fo sho.

I really enjoyed NYNY, even though I didn't actually stay there. 

The roller coaster was a big draw. It wasn't the best coaster I've been on, but it was still a lot of fun!

The casino was great. Not as smoky as some casinos, and they had $5 blackjack which is always a plus with me!

The theming is also great. It looks just like New York! The restaurants were great too, as well as the Hershey store! Also they have Zumanity here which was INCREDIBLE.

I loved spending time in this resort. Wish I had stayed here instead of Excalibur!

$25 early check in fee? In a sour mood before even getting to the room so 1 star it is.

Also, there is s $30 resort fee that includes must haves like local calls and faxes...but there is no coffee pot in the room.

I enjoyed my stay at this hotel!  The room was clean and spacious, it is located on the southern end of the strip and there is plenty to do in the hotel.   My one complaint is the resort fee.  They should just hide that fee into your stay....not make is secrete because it really doesn't give you anything.  No discounts. No free ride tickets. Just a $20 per day fee on top of your nightly rate.

We were in Vegas last weekend for our annual girls trip. There are 4 of us that go, all of us are in our 20's. We stayed at NY NY and had a very nice time. I was nervous after reading the reviews, but we had a very different experience. Let me start off by saying that none of us are very picky. The room was standard (towels could have been nicer), but overall, no major complaints. I've had better, had worse. We had a lot of fun at the pool. They have a DJ that spins in the afternoon and he played good music all day. They don't check your bag on the way in, so I recommend packing your own alcohol and snacks to save some $$. There are plenty of options for food in the hotel which was very nice. They have late might menus at many of their restaurants, so it's easy to grab a bite to eat on your way back in after a night out. We'll likely stay there again, but we do prefer to be on the other end of the strip.

New York New York is horrible, to be brutally honest. We got there, checked in, and when we got to our room we learned that they had put us in a different room than we had requested. My husband called the front desk and talked to Emily (he says he's 99% sure her name was Emily), who informed us that there were no king rooms available (despite us booking our room THREE MONTHS AGO) but that we could be moved the next day and she would waive the daily resort charge for the entire trip to apologize for the inconvenience this caused us (as we had to interrupt our plans for the next day so we could move rooms). We were greatly appreciative of that. 

The restaurants and stores are pretty good here, like there's a good variety. 

Some of the rooms can be extremely loud. I got four hours of sleep our first night here (not an exaggeration - I took this number right off of my Fitbit app!) because the first room we were in was right next to an elevator that was running during all hours of the night. Along with that, we dealt with a terrible AC unit that was ice cold but when you tried to turn on the heater, it would start smoking. There were people screaming at each other in the middle of the night. The beds are somewhat comfortable. The bathrooms are pretty awkwardly set up, with the door barely clearing the toilet. It's an aging hotel and it shows. 

I thought the arcade was pretty cool until we realized that half of the games don't even work. 

We checked out this morning to make sure that the resort charge was in fact waived. The individual who helped us was Denise, who was oh so pleasant (sarcasm). She confirmed that the resort charge was waived for ONE DAY out of "goodwill" and reminded us once again that we didn't get the room we had reserved the first night because it just wasn't available. She was so careless and showed no desire to make it better, even after I commented saying that it was shady that we were lied to and that I'd be mentioning this in my review. 

Overall, I will never ever stay here again. This hotel and its employees don't care about their guests, they just care about making money and they're willing to lie and lose the trust of their guests to do it.

A four star hotel? Really? the rooms felt like a high class motel ... dark and definitely past it's prime days. If this was an "upgraded room" I wonder what the original must have looked like !!!

at least it was clean and comfortable so can't really complain except it's not worth the star rating at all!

Loved the New York New York. Staff was friendly, great service, hotel room was clean and beautiful. We had a view of the roller coaster and also the MGM grand. We were able to check in early, our room was ready for us which made it very convenient to drop off our luggage and freshen up before hitting the strip. Casino and restaurants were great as well! Definitely had a great stay!

I've always wanted to stay at NYNY and I was excited to get a good deal on our room for one night. The room was pretty nice but our view of a roof kind of sucked.

Also it was a tiny bit disturbing to have a vent open to the hallway on the opposite side of our bathroom mirror. 

And I always wonder just how long do hotels let room service dirty dishes sit in the hallway? There was the same tray the whole time we were there.
Gross!

I was sad to leave after one night though since we were really enjoying ourselves. I'd totally stay again but try to get a room with a better view.

Just took a uninvited cold shower after a 18 hour day at work with 6 hours remaining to sleep before I do it again. Front desk manager said after I told her this that "oh we can send a technician to fix it now." Unhappy tired and upset I declined. She said "well I'm not sure what I can do For you." I imagine they have heard of compensation but maybe I am wrong and cold and in a crappy mood since i just took a cold shower.

Honestly, the facility is getting really run down. I stayed in a Marquis Suite at NYNY about a year ago and it wasn't bad. On my most recent trip, however, they didn't have any Marquis Suites available so I went with the Spa Suite. The room was very sparse and dark, and the wallpaper was ripping off the walls in places. The carpet looked VERY old, and likely was the reason the room had a musty smell. Additionally, the bathroom sink made noises all night long for 4 nights straight. After the first night, we asked for a room upgrade, but again, they claimed not to have anything available. I am an Mlife member and generally try to stay at MGM resorts, but I think my days staying at NYNY are over. This is my first time writing a bad review for an Mlife facility.

This review is for the casino, I haven't actually stayed at this hotel. 

As for the casino, it was one of the first casinos we were in that we felt had 'young' games....you have got to play BATTLESHIP! Had tons of fun on that machine, as long as you have four people sitting down...it brings back childhood memories of playing the actual game:)
Next, we had so much fun on the electronic CRAPS game.....that was something we hadn't found at other casinos so all in all....we really enjoyed the casino game choices they offered and also getting a quick massage at the top of the escalators, and there was Ben and Jerry's around the corner, pleasantly memorable casino that we will visit again on our next visit.....too MUCH FUN

Our hotel room was robbed tonight as we stepped out for a little over 2 hours.  This was definitely an inside job, as our door was locked.  

Earlier in the evening we went up to our room to freshen up before heading out.  There was a Hispanic woman who was strangely following us as we walked to our room. When we stopped to open our door she slowly walked past us.  It was strange and I made a comment to my husband that I almost thought she was going to confront us.  

We got ready and left the hotel to walk the strip.  We didn't get very far though, and turned back to NYNY and had dinner then gambled a bit.  We then decided to go back to our room.  

Upon walking in I noticed an empty overturned coffee cup partially under our bed, with light lipstick on the rim.  Right then my husband noticed his Adidas were missing.  As we looked around it was obvious our things were rifled through and my cellphone I left to charge was also gone.    Other items were missing, including his wallet and my cash. 

Called Security who came up to take the report. Gave her the coffee cup which she said she'd "take into evidence" and we questioned her about checking the elevator cameras for the Hispanic woman or anyone holding a similar coffee cup (she laughed and said that was a good idea).  She said we'd need to wait until morning for the next shift (???!?!)  She went to the armoire and asked if we had used the plastic laundry bag that was usually kept there. We didn't.  And it was gone. She mentioned that thieves will use that bag to hold all the items they remove from the room.  We had no idea it was even there.  Obviously an in-house employee would, right?  

So now we lay wide awake in a different room, same hotel.  Management moved us to a different room and credited our account $100 to be used as food\/beverage credit.  Yeah, sure, the first thing we want to do is leave our room and belongings to go spend that credit.  

Up until now we were enjoying our stay here. Now we can't wait to get the F outta here.  Noticed someone else wrote on TripAdvisor that they were robbed at this same hotel earlier this month while they were asleep in their room (!!!!).  Terrible nightmare experience and even worst is the nonchalant way security treated our ordeal.

I stayed here previously at the Park Avenue view suite.

Hotel room-I wasn't a fan of the room. For a suite it was kind of small. AC was strong but was very loud, good view of the strip, bathroom looked old and not renovated. It actually looked like a motel bathroom. Room decor was very 80s, big tv, comfy beds and pillows, walls were really thin. I could hear our neighbors having sex (it was kind of hot)

Hotel\/accommodations- check in was by fast, elevators no line and fast, hallways clean, staff very nice, pool was rather small for the size of the hotel, wifi included in resort fee, valet was actually really quick.

Restaurants-I have to say that this hotel has a ton of selections for food which I liked about this hotel. And a lot of choices to fit a person budget.

Staff-service and staff was awesome. Everyone was welcoming and smiling, lots of staff and security. Felt safe and nice that staff acknowledges you.

I would stay here again for the price.

We LOVED just about everything about this hotel. Its not gigantic like the MGM where you hike a mile to get anywhere. The strip is easy to get to no matter where you are in the hotel. Theme gives it character, and there are plenty of dining options for every budget. We arrived at 9am, did not wait in line, and got the marquis suite for 140$ a night. If you can get this room DO IT. View was amazing, plenty of space, and the Jacuzzi was a great bonus. 

Casino is small but we kind of liked that. Italian place has buy one get one free breakfast when you stay there during the week -  the food was delicious. plenty of shops, and easy access to MGM sky bridge and Luxor\/Mandalay tram at excalibur. 

Location is a bit south on the strip but no biggie. We walked to the north end and caught a lyft ride back for 7$. 

Only complaint was the smug bartender at the center bar, but i guess everyone has a bad day... everyone else at this place was VERY friendly and helpful. 

Disclaimer - I read a TON of reviews about this hotel before we booked and had some mild doubts based on reviews, but did not experience one issue while staying there.

This was my first time staying in one of the big "theme hotels" in Vegas & I was not disappointed. The rooms were spacious, modern & tasteful decoration, plenty of storage space for my GF & I. The bathroom alone was big enough for 3 people to sleep in plus gorgeous tile work & a multi setting shower head made us feel like royalty. I can't say enough about how comfortable the bed was either. The pillow top mattress was just as inviting as my bed at home & the sheets were clean & soft, I had no problem going to bed & staying there well after sunrise ha ha ha. The only things I would complain about is the pool was a bit smaller than it probably should be for a hotel of this size as it was pretty dang crowded & the line to check into our room was a lot longer than it should have been & we ended up waiting quite a while. 
Overall though the NYNY exceeded my expectations & I would definitely consider it again on return trips.

I have never had a bad experience here. In three trips the people have always been gray and the rooms have been nice. The suites are very nice for the price. It is in no way a luxury hotel but it is a great place to stay.

I stayed in this hotel and enjoyed the location, hospitality, cleanliness, and options available. The piano bar was great. Only issue, our room was extremely noisy as we were next to a room with a jet tub and every time our neighbors filled the tub, there was a horrible screeching sound in the walls. ( our room was 1620 ). The pool was a bIt noisy with rollercoaster going by over and over again, but they have done a good job trying to muffle the sounds with music.
Nice casino, but 8 deck shoes and only 6 to 5 Blackjack!  Greedy casinos have built these mega casinos  without steeling  more  odds from the game!  Just  say No to 6 to 5 Blackjack!

Better than a three, maybe not actually a four, but since I had to pick one I went up instead of down (since the positives were greater than the negatives).

We started with a "Strip view" Madison Avenue room; we paid extra for the "view". We were more than disappointed with this view (or lack thereof). We immediately requested to move and were just as quickly accommodated - the service was great. The view we ended up with was on the back side away of the hotel looking at the mountains and the city, but we both agreed it was better and it was actually spectacular.

The location is OK, but OK is all it is (one of the negatives). At least when you walk out of the hotel you are directly on the strip. But, you have a bit of a walk to get to the main action.

The rooms and hotel (and casino) were clean and well kept up.
The wifi worked well through-out our room and lobby.
The bed was comfortable (a little on the firmer side), but the pillows were all the fluffy type that go flat within an hour of laying on them.

The casino is in the hotel lobby rather than an attached separate building; I found this convenient if you want to gamble. There were slot machines as well as table games, but this was one of the smaller casinos we visited. With that said, it was nice to have them right there when you come down to the lobby, or on the way back to your room.

The smoke was overwhelming in the casino (and the restaurants since they are shared space). I know, I know, this is Vegas what did I expect? Sure, there was smoke in ALL the casinos we visited, but some\/many of the casinos did a much better job of controlling the odor. This was a large part of the negative for this hotel, since the smell was everywhere. We expected a nice hotel like this one to smell better since even some of the much older casinos (on Fremont) did a better job with the smoke smell. Here, as soon as you enter the building you can't get away it.

The hotel provides many options to eat, but none of the places we ate would be considered fantastic. We ate at both of the nicer restaurants and neither one of us was impressed.

The parking garage was free, easily accessed, and has two entrances into the hotel\/casino.

I might stay here again, but I most certainly would look around before I did. Overall, we enjoyed our stay here. Would I recommend the hotel? Probably, but I would also suggest they compare before they decide.

I wasn't expecting the rooms to be all that nice here due to being next to Excalibur...(which has crappy rooms) but I was really pleasantly surprised. The style of the rooms inside reminded me of the comsopolitan's decor. They were very modern and clean. I thought compared to the price of other similar rooms at other hotels - the price was fair too. I would stay here again, for sure. However, we were given vouchers for the "breakfast buffet" but we ended up going to the wrong one. The restraunt (I think its asian themed) thats next to the elevators to the rooms - SUCKS. Dont go there for breakfast if you want a quality meal. We paid way too much money for the "buffet" which consisted of nasty eggs, boring hashbrowns, bacon and overpriced orange juice. They didnt even have belgian waffles, pancakes, or french toast (pretty obvious breakfast staples) and there was no variety of tasty food. The cantelope they surprisingly offered was dry, tastless and out of season. I stayed at a Quality Inn for $50 a night in a not so great part of San Diego last weekend, and their FREE breakfast in the lobby was much better and had more variety. So thats sayin' something!

I loved the New York-New York Hotel & Casino.

I didn't stay here, didn't gamble here, didn't see a show here, and didn't ride the rollercoaster. I did eat here once, at Gallagher's Steakhouse.  And I walked through it a bunch, as I stayed at The Excaliber, and NY-NY was kind of a gateway to the rest of the strip.  But mostly, it was my second favorite casino - Paris was my favorite - and if I had to choose only one casino to remain in Vegas, it would have been NY-NY.

This is because Las Vegas is a strange, frightening place. I grew up in the suburbs of NYC and have lived in Philly and the suburbs of Philly. I'm an east coast lad.

And Vegas is NOT the east coast, in big and small ways.  It's a different color! It's all pink and yellow and red... and there are no trees, except palm trees (which make no sense in 35deg Vegas February weather), and it's flat everywhere, but then there are these mountains rising in the distance... the buildings are low and the city just... stops.  You can walk 10 minutes away from the strip and find motels and fast food and a whole lot of... nothing.  No traffic, no apartments... open, undeveloped space.  Where do the people that work in that city live?  It baffles me.  Try walking in any direction when you're in Center City, Philly or Times Square, NY... are you going to find undeveloped lots or lazy motels?

Vegas is truly the city that doesn't sleep, with old women sitting at slots at 4 in the morning.  Smoking appears to be allowed everywhere, and Hispanics in hoodies line up in rows along the sidewalk trying to get you to take cards advertising prostitutes by snapping them back and forth, as if you'd say no to 10 in a row and then yes to the 11th.  Everything is a mockup of somewhere else, a city that doesn't have its own soul so it borrows and exaggerates on everything else it sees.  Then it bedazzles it, adds a light show, and charges twice as much.

Ok, getting off track.  Basically... when I was outside, and I looked over at the NY-NY... it felt a little like home.  and when I was overwhelmed by the smoke and the flashing lights and the hooker cards... it was a good feeling.  And when I went inside the casino... that fake version of NYC felt more real than any other place I went in Vegas.

Less melodramatically... I liked the casinos who stayed true to their themes.  Luxor is a giant pyramid with a sphinx outside, but inside, it's just a sleek black and gold colored casino.  And it's the same with most of them.  But the city themed ones, Paris and NY, they took it to heart.  The stores and restaurants a mocked up to make you feel like you're on streets outside, the foods and gifts stay true to the theme as well.  Outside and inside, they're dedicated to the conceit.  And I liked that a lot.

So I can't tell you about the rooms or the tables or the rides, but I can tell you I was happy NY-NY was right in Sin City, and if you're an east coast adventurer looking for a feel of home, this caricature of it might be able to get you through.
Clean but no real amenities. No coffee or tea in the room, no refrigerator, etc. For this amount of money, I want more!

The Casino: 
Okay, but not a place to be for very long as it is very crowded all the time. 

The Hotel: 
We reserved a 2 bed hotel room and once we checked-in (which was on time) they told us "sorry we are all out of 2 bed rooms." This is seriously not acceptable, but what could we do. We got a roll out bed with our one-bed room.

Food: 
There are not that many food options here. Pizza, fast food, and unhealthy options. The only thing that was a plus, was the 24 hour Starbucks inside. 

The nightlife: 
The bars were a-ok. Nothing special. There was one bar with a man signing Friday\/Saturday night that was so loud and had a horrible voice. I don't want to sound mean, but it was awful! Every time I passed by there, I had to literally cover my ears. 

So why 3 stars, if this sounds like a 1 star place? 
The room was clean, comfy bed, and decent view. I loved the hotel theme and there is a cool looking rollercoaster, although I would never go on it in 105+ degrees outside. It is centrally located on the Strip (South), and near to the airport. The employees were generally nice and responsive, except for the bed issue which was horrible. 

Would I come here again? 
Maybe. Only if it was the best deal.

My two best friends and I have watched the NFL's "BIg Game" every year for the past 6 years at the New York New York.  It has become a cherished tradition, but we did not receive an invitation this past year and we were very disappointed.  I called Casino Host Barbara Barnot, explained the situation, and she immedietly made things right. Wow, did she make us feel like welcomed guests. Tremendously improved my opinion of the NYNY. I could not thank her enough. I can't wait to come back next year!

P.S. Won a bunch shooting dice....and then Tom Brady took it all back, like he always does.

First off, this has got to be one of the best themed hotel casinos in Las Vegas.  The exterior of this hotel\/casino is completely different from the standard rectangular buildings you see surrounding it.  The exterior shows different buildings resembling the New York City skyline.  
The interior has a Greenwich Village feel and you really feel like you walked out of the casino into an attached neighborhood.  There is always something going on entertainment wise and I hope to take in some of these on my next visit.   
Even when you walk out of the casino, there is so much that is within a short walk; a pedestrian bridge to MGM, a short walk to Monte Carlo, Shake Shack, Bruxie and many other places.  
I had a room in the Empire tower and it was a very nice room, spacious and very clean.  When you exit the elevator, you have to make a right turn to enter the hallway for your room so you don't hear the elevator even in the nearest room.  
Depending on the time of year and what is going on in Las Vegas, the rooms can be very reasonable for a nice hotel and I would recommend it for families as the Boardwalk upstairs has family friendly activities such as video games and the roller coaster.

First off, knocking off a star because of the recent parking and valet fees, which really was one of the key reasons we even come to Vegas.  Free valet is one of those luxuries that we don't get anywhere else and now that is gone.  

Make sure you become an M-Life member so you at least only have to pay for parking or valet once for any MGM property (which is like half of Vegas practically).

New York New York has really changed since the last time I visited this resort.  It was our first time seeing the new T-Mobile Arena and the huge outdoor entertainment venue dubbed "The Park" which also coincides with MGM's future plans to rebrand the Monte Carlo.

Our kids loved Hershey's Chocolate World...and there is so much to see and enjoy in this resort. We stayed an extra day on our recent trip to Vegas and wanted to stay at NY-NY but the rooms were sold out.  We opted for the Luxor (bad decision) instead.  Don't make my same mistake ;)

One note:  we tried the Shake Shack for the first time and we're blown away by how good the burgers are.  This was a fantastic addition to this resort.  Make sure you check it out!

Nice hotel. Quite big. Accommodating.

I got left by my family because I refused to wake up at 4AM to go to the grand canyon, so I stayed and ordered Room Service. I love Room Service! 

We got a room with a city\/street view.... and what we got......... A nice (sarcasm) view of the roller coaster. I saw the M&M shop, and Coca cola store, but that's about all the "street" "city" view I got. Thanks NYNY? (sarcasm again)
Main bar after five minutes of waiting: oh hey [high giggle] we had last call. The bar was empty and it was before 2am. Unacceptable service.

This is a nice clean up to date casino that caters to a younger clientele which I like... but they did a poor job capturing the vibe of NYC.  They need to have food and beverage options available later at night and earlier in the morning.  

The only 24 hr operation they have is a generic diner "America."  Maybe they could've themed that spot as Tom's diner or more popularly known as Monk's Cafe from Seinfeld.  I think that would be a real hit.

Worst hotel EVER!!!! Booked 3 nights , all 3 days we stayed NEVER , i repeat never got housekeeping , after i called numerous times to let them know we havent got attended too since day 1!!!! People were rude , had a man drop a glass on my foot that was drunk , my daughter fell back in one of their chairs they had in front of the lil pizza place they have in the casino ...rooms were average , nothing like the pics on the site! I will never stay here again , im sticking with Mandalay Bay!!! Gorgeous hotel , they attend to your needs and thats how it should be!!!!

In all fairness I have not stayed in the hotel, so this review will be confined to the public areas. The casino is dark, cavernous and loud, making it seedier than the actual New York (no easy task). All that being said, they still have the nerve to have high table limits. The steak-house, however was good, as is Nine Fine Irishmen. All in all it is worth a look.

I've always enjoyed my stay at NYNY, but this visit didn't start off great! When we arrived, we went to the invited guests line where there was a family of eight being assisted by two staff members. We were next, but after nearly forty minutes waiting, while a whole lot of nothing was taking place, we were finally helped. We were never acknowledged or given an apology for the wait during this time. The woman to the side stood there with no expression and looked to be making small notes in a notebook as if she was being trained by the women who was helping us. Not only did the two of them lack emotion, we could not understand the woman helping us. Between the low, monotone, scripted lines, and accent, she was nearly impossible to understand. As she finished with us, she did tell us "thank you for waiting" almost under her breath. Not a good way to make you feel as a valued guest.

Rooms are nice and clean. NYNY isn't the most updated, hip place to be anymore. A lot of older slots; a nice, but ordinary pool; good location on the strip; and a little more relaxing atmosphere as compared to some other casinos. I did find the best cocktail waitress! She was fast and efficient! Kept the drinks coming while I was on the machines. And a pretty good Michael Jackson impersonator performed on the stage by the table games! If you need a thrill, ride the roller coaster!

I love you Vegas and I will see you soon.  We were lucky and got a great cocktail waitress who was bringing us drinks every 10 minutes.  We kept tipping and she kept coming.  I also love the bar in NY NY called Nine Fine Irishmen.

New York New York is a nice hotel, aside from the rooms. The rooms were a bit dated and there were no refrigerators. That would have been nice to have. The rollercoaster wakes you up much earlier than you would like after a night of partying. 

That being said, this hotel has some amazing food options. Any mood you are in, they have it. Hot Dogs, Asian, Italian, etc. The decor inside really makes you feel like you are in New York...that is if every street had slot machines on them. I would probably stay here again, but ask for a room away from the rollercoaster.

So hard to rate\/review hotels since there's so many positive and negatives based on experience.  The positives are something of a perk.  The negatives are due to inconvenience or experience.  So here's my list.

Positives:
- Cheap room rates!
- Plenty of food options (Food Court)
- Cheap tables (BJ\/Craps\/Roulette)
- New Beds!  So damn comfortable!  
- Parking structure is fairly close to the lobby.

Negatives:
- Non peak weekend and our rooms were located in a smoking tower.
- It was either way too warm in our room or too frickn cold!  They need to go digital on the thermostats.
- Our room was close to the Roller Coaster....  Thicker glass please!  I have sensitive ears when Im hungover in the morning and I hear the roller coaster with people screaming.  =)
- Everyone won money but me!  Better to lose hundreds at a game than to spend it all on a stripper.....  So I've heard..... lol!

In a word, blah. Slow front desk, dated rooms, no coffee maker or fridge.  Rooms are clean but tired, staff is pleasant.  I travel extensively for work and these rooms are poorly equipped compared to a Hampton inn type hotel. Super slow front desk.  Really really slow.

I never knew they built hotels this big this side of Moscow in the socialist era. Luckily the queues move faster. The rooms are as standard as they can be. Don't even contemplate making a 2-minute telephone call from your room, though. You can have quite a few beers for the charge.

Donna Oum! from Las Vegas was the best dealer I've ever had at a black jack table. Personality and her true soul are pure and good. The roller coaster was also awesome. The pizza is great! This is one of my favorite casinos.... Ever.

I stayed back in October of 2015 and I had an amazing time! I have a life goal at staying at every hotel on the strip at least once, so I didn't plan on staying here a 2nd time but we are! The room is so nice and the bed is VERY soft and comfortable. I'm one of those people that likes to be sleeping 'on a cloud' lol. And theres literally something to do for every age group. The only thing that sucked was at 2:30am when we were stumbling around with the munchies, all of the restaurants and quick service food spots were closed...which meant it was time to go to bed lol! Can't wait to come back and check out the pool!

I hadn't been to Vegas in 15 years much has hanged. The strip blew my mind. My husband and I took our 2 boys ages 8 and 10.  I chose NY NY because I was told it was one of the best kid friendly hotels and room rates were low. We got incredible value! Our kids practically lived in the arcade! There are so many great places to eat or grab a slice of pizza, Deli sandwich hot dog ala Cony Island style. 
The hotel is across the street from M&M World and Coca-Cola store. Kids loved it!
We were all too scared to ride the roller coaster, but enjoyed watching others screaming by us. Maybe next time we will be brave enough because we will definitely be returning.

I Came to Vegas recently with a group of about 9 girls to celebrate a birthday. We picked the New York New York because it was cheap and we knew they had several casual bar and restaurant choices which we thought would work well for a large group. As a hotel it was satisfactory but it didn't take us long to realize that the New York New York is not one of the 'happening' spots and we spent most of our time on the other side of the strip. That being said, here are some pros and cons. 
Pro's
-The mini New York skyline and landmarks are pretty spectacular. I think from the outside this is one of the most visually exciting spots in Vegas.
-The rooms were well decorated, spacious and comfortable.
-The cocktail waitresses were attentive with the free drinks even when I was sitting at the penny slots.
-I ordered a birthday cake a few days in advance of my arrival. It was at the door beautifully decorated at the exact time I had specified. 
-As mentioned above, there are a ton of cheap and fast food options downstairs that range from burgers to a New York Deli. While none of the food was spectacular I will say that it was a great alternative to going out for a pricey group dinner at a sit down place every night. We were able to bring food up to our room and chow down with our own cocktails while getting ready for the evening and listening to music on the iPod dock which was a nice in-room amenity. 
-Guests at New York New York can also use the pool at the Monte Carlo where we found plenty or sun, chaise lounges and tasty frozen cocktails. 
Cons
-The vibe inside the casino isn't nearly as bustling and high energy as other casinos that we stopped in. The hay day for this place has clearly come and gone and the crowd here seemed a little sorry. 
-Our room keys got demagnetized and wouldn't work about 3 times. It was a huge pain to constantly have to traipse downstairs, through the casino and wait in line at the front desk. They did give us a $35 credit when we complained - but still- the constant key issues were very annoying.
-I came down for coffee one morning as some of the restaurants were opening up and there were big garbage dumpsters out for guests to smell and see. Although I like the New York city street theme, I don't need it to be that authentic.
-Based on what I've heard from other friends that go to Vegas a lot, I can tell that neither the New York New York or the Monte Carlo have the best pool scene. Both pools were pleasant enough but lacked that party atmosphere you look for when you are on a Vegas vacay. 
-The action is at the other end of the strip which isn't exactly close when it's a million degrees outside. 
New York New York served its purpose but I would never stay there again, or recommend it. The money we spent shuttling back and forth to the more exciting end of the strip could have just been spent on a hotel that was closer to the action.

Love this Casino.... 

I walked around and felt as if I was walking in the streets of New York City...!

The roller coaster ride is pretty intense, you must try it at least once..!!

I love the huge arcade full of all sort of games...! It was super fun..!

Very poor emergency medical service this evening (11:50pm) when a young man with his head face down on a table and barely responsive. Security personnel with obviously NO MEDICAL training atempted to help and were extremely defensive with myself and my so. Both Firefights\/EMTs trying to assist. We were both told to back off and " We have it handled, we deal with this every day" they obviously did not know what they were doing, and failed to call for professional emergency medical care. This type of ignorance is unacceptable in this day and age and is extremely costly (liability) to any business. Wake up.

We parked on top of the New York New York building and saw the largest view from the very top. New York New York casually plays swing music in the elevator she inside the lobby. Once entering in, it's connected to a large arcade, restaurants and bars and casinos. The bright sight of their logo shines real big and catches eyes. The building is connected to most shopping centers and you can spot the rollercoaster from underneath of the casino. It's one of my favorite buildings in Las Vegas.

will i come back again, probably, will need to think abut it.


Cons: Muppet at front desk added up our iniial room fee wrong by over $600 what a mess. rectified though
You pay $20 to have access to wifi its a resort fee, not great. should be covered in room fee etc
bathroom so so, the showers are old and a bit out dated, but clean so not all bad.
tv channels or lack there of, alot were locked out.
cigarette smoke in our room, even though it was none smoking..unacceptable.

Pros
the reason i gave it 3 stars where it really should have been 2, was the room service
room servie was great, goodfood big portions, nice staff.
great view of roller coaster and vegas
good eaterys down in casino
pool was good a few hot chicks down there, always welcome!
beds soooo comfy, lookin at buying the same bed for home!
chin chin breaky super good
looks great outside the hotel

We stayed in the hotel, the room was lovely.  We had a panaramic view of the strip, which was beautiful.  There were no extra frills in the room, it was a simple suite without a mini bar or jacuzzi tub; however, it was clean and quiet.  We ordered room service for breakfast, it was delivered in the allocated time and was well prepared.  The prices were high, a pot of coffee would have been $8.95 + mandatory $3 service fee + 18% gratuity.

The casino restrooms were acceptable, but not amazing.  There were all the necessary items available; however, there was no hand lotion or other frills available tht someone gambling for 2-3 hours might appreciate.  

We visited the the Sunday Brunch at Ting Ting restaurant, and it was confusing.  There was a very limited selection of brunch food, the food quality was not in par with the price, and the service was slow.  I do not recommend it and I regret wasting my Sunday brunch at this location.

The casino dealers were, without exception, over 40 years old.  They were pleasant and nice, with the exception of pit boss Bob Miener.  We placed lots of dealer bets for tips, which they seemed to enormously appreciate.  When all was said and done, we left lots of money with the casino.

A friend stayed here last week for a work event and we decided to check out the piano bar. Very fun place. I would go back for it alone. It's right next to Galliger's steakhouse.

Warning though, after 7pm on weekends they charge a fee to sit at a table in this place. We stayed for the 6pm show with no table charge and it was really a blast. Fun crowd, good songs, etc... 

The 8pm show had a much larger crowd and we didn't want to pay the $25 per person table fee so we just hung out in the bar area.

Of all the times I've been to Vegas, I have never entered this establishment.  So thanks to a special player rate promotion offer, I decided to gave this place a try since we decided to take the kids on this Vegas trip and figured they should have a kid friendly area with the coaster they have there.  When we arrived to check in, the front desk staff were very nice and friendly.  I was told that our room was quite far from the elevators, but I can call the next morning to have them change rooms for me.  What really stopped me from giving this place a 4 star was the actual walk to our room from the elevators.  It was a bit confusing with so many twists and turns just to get to our room.  It really felt life forever to just get to our room.  The lady that checked us in wasn't kidding about being far from the elevators.  The rooms were small, but clean.  Another reason for the 3 stars was the TV.  We had issues with the signal and the channels went black, so that was a bummer.  At least the wifi was working (comes with the resort fee), so the kids had something to keep them busy while we were in our room.  The next morning we were able to get a room closer to the elevator, so our next day stay was a little better.   The TV worked fine in the beginning, but we ended up having the same signal issue as the last room later on that night.

Another pet peeve that I had was the cocktail service when I was at the tables.  While I was the table to kill some time before dinner, it took a while for someone to come by to take drink orders and when the girl finally came and I placed my order, she never came back with my drink!  I was sitting there for a good hour since my order and was so bummed that I didn't get my drink before I had to leave for dinner.

The kids seemed to enjoy themselves when we took them to the arcade here.  I think I'm just spoiled by my stay from places like the Palazzo to Encore, so NYNY wasn't impressive to me.  But honestly, in comparison to Luxor... it's way better and the prices aren't going to leave a hole in your pockets for a night stay.

Decided to make a last minute trip to Vegas over the weekend, and New York York, New York had reasonable prices for the Saturday night. Since we were only staying for one night, we decided to book the Park Avenue with Strip View. 

We arrived around 12pm on a Saturday, and check in took about 20 minutes. The front desk personnel was nice, and we were checked in to  room 3024. 
Room is definitely small, but looked like it had been renovated recently. Bed was comfortable. My biggest complaint was the bathroom. Super tiny, forget about having two people in there at one time. The view of the strip was ok. We were facing the airport.

The lively hood, and theme of the hotel is pretty awesome. 
 
Overall, we had a good stay. I would consider staying here again if I was going to be in town for one night.

Like I said, we stayed here in November during the Pacquaio vs. Cotto fight weekend. We booked this probably before or after our intended stay in September so the price was a deal! I believe we got a night free!

Now, prior to actually staying here I didn't even know where you head in order to check in, but wherever the taxi drops you off, you head to the left of the casino and you'll find the registration. 

What I semi-disapprove of is how there are FOUR towers. Now this was only a downside because we wanted to be near our cousin, but he ended up being in a completely different tower. Our floor was located in the Century towers and I believe our room had part of the word ROK on it, we're still trying to fig that out. 

Twanyways....we had a strip-view room which meant we walked down endless hallways to get to the LAST room. Now, if you don't care much for views, which I certainly don't care about anymore, I'd recommend letting them know you want a room closer to the elevator.

Now, I thought the distance from our room to the elevator was pretty long, but that wasn't until I visited my cousin's room. I don't remember which tower he was located in, but it was behind the eateries. Where I expected his room to be, we continued to walk in about 2-3 more hallways!!! SO LONG!! That's terrible if you're going to be staggering to your room at 3 in the morning!! Or if you're lazy like me! (and my ankle is still healing from being fractured)

Other than that, the location of the hotel is good on the strip and it has direct access to Excalibur and MGM. I didn't discover the Excalibur bridge until the day we were leaving.
