this is more of a reply to the comment.  i want to say thanks for having an arcade\/midway area for the kids.  the arcade isnt bad its just pricy.  it has some old games that should go imo, but they got some new hits.  several arcades have closed since i last visited.  they offer cool little card to put credits on too.  lots of families playing too.  the roller coaster is short and thrilling for those who are afraid of heights.  u can hear the screams on the street even with all the other noise.
NY-NY is a huge hotel. Just like all the other casino\/hotels next to each other. Although this hotel is nice, there is nothing really that stood out to me. I would come and stay here as well.

Great hotel overall.  Stayed for 4 nights and have no major complaints.  Lots to do in the hotel and see, decent food options the Italian place is delicious!

A few notes:  they gave me a hard time at check in because my sister in law told them the wrong last name, after a slight hissy fit they solved the issue.

One day we had a dirty pillow case, house cleaning came quickly to solve the problem, our room was quite dusty the entire stay as well.

Overall we had a nice quiet and fun stay!  I would certainly return.

Younger crowd, tables are priced high compared to some of the cheaper casinos nearby, but the women that go here are better looking.  The dealers are more stoic than some of the cheaper casinos and drink ladies are slow but the rooms are always nice, even the cheap ones, and the pool is filled with hard bodies at all times.

I've always been interested in checking this hotel out, and while I didn't stay here, I greatly enjoyed the amenities provided by the hotel.

New York New York had a bombardment of sound and lights throughout the arcade game section and the line formation for the roller coaster.  I hollered at someone working there who was kind enough to show me how to get to the street scene with all the restaurants and shops that led into the casino area. 

I was incredibly charmed by the miniature city with the cobble stone streets, the manhole covers, and street lights. Having grown up in NJ I was prepared to be critical of the "authentic" NY food options, but I was pleasantly surprised. At the delicatessen the Reuben was a real Reuben served with a super creamy potato salad and a crunchy pickle. It was a wholly satisfying meal for under ten bucks! If you have a group with you the best option is getting the family meal deal over at the fish and chips counter.  The offering is respectable in terms of quality, but the portion size is tremendous.  Only con here is that they didn't have any malt vinegar.

I don't know why so many people bitch about a hotel room in Vegas your in vegas who cares what the room looks like you just need a bed to sleep on your going be out doing things the whole time your in vegas but overall I loved my experience at the New York New York it's clean and in a great spot I definitely recommend staying here when you travel to vegas and also the wife and I loved the Zumanity show they have at the casino we will definitely come back to this casino
Clean rooms and on the strip.  I love the theme.  One thing:  You have to step up high into bathtub\/shower combo.

We were upgraded to a spa suite in the Empire Tower for no cost, and what an awesome upgrade it was! Nothing beats a hot jetted spa when you get back into your room after a loooooong night\/early morning of loud music and way to many "drinks". We stayed here for 4 days, was a nice place with alot to see and do. I didnt feel the need to dress up in a casual suit everytime we ventured out, like in other casions we have gone too. Great location on the strip too! Skybridge connects your right into MGM and near Studio 54 & Rainforest Cafe. Room service was fast and of good quality. Not the fanciest, but who really stays in their room or even at their own casino much during a trip... ROK was fun, got bottle service and they sat 3 Lakers (at the time Ariza, Walton, & Farmar) at the table next to us which was a huge thrill for this lifetime Lakers fan. One of the best memories in Vegas I have for any trip.

As a native New Yorker who no longer lives there, this place was a little creepy. Walking from self-parking down into the casino, if you stop to use the restroom, you'll see signs for "Central Park" and "Bryant Park", which was a bit surreal. On the casino floor we walked through areas which felt like mini\/Hollywood versions of the village. We parked here first before walking around to Excalibur and Mandalay Bay, and we walked over the "Brooklyn Bridge" on our way there. I can't say I'm a fan of the fake NYC stuff, the fake Arc De Triumph and Eiffel Tower at Paris; it just creeps me out.

The casino floor was pretty nice though. Later we came back to eat and do some slots before heading over to Penn and Teller, and ate at the Bar at Times Square. For the strip, they had a good happy hour: $5 drinks and 50% of food, which meant $7.50 cheeseburgers and fries. The kitchen messed up the hubby's burger order, and the bartender was very nice about getting a new one and comped us one drink. They were very nice, and the food was pretty good. And most of the other HH's we saw were drinks only.

So: creepy, nice floor, good HH at the Bar at Times Square! Kinda wish we had done Zumanity too, looked cool!

When in Vegas, you eat a lot of buffets.  So you never know where you're gonna be when you need to drop a load.  I can tell you that the NYny is one of the best places to be when you have to drop a deuce!

Its not the nicest, fanciest bathroom but i like it because instead of the flimsy modular metal stalls that separate the bowls, they have solid doors that go all the way to the floor with out gaps at the hinges and bottom.  So you don't have to worry about what sounds may come out of your stall, you can just let er' rip!  
The stalls also have an occupied or vacant indicator, like on an airplane bathroom, so you don't have to turn your neck and to see if someone's feet are in the stall to figure out if its occupied or not!  GENIUS!

What i also like about NY NY is they are green, bathroom has the Dyson Air Blade, swipe your hands in and out 2 or 3 times and they are dry!  no paper towels needed!  Trash cans around the casino say "we recycle your bottles for you"

And i walked away $100 ahead! (if you work for the IRS, I lost it at another casino later)

This hotel charges $22.50 each day for a resort fee even though you don't use the gym or the pool. Their player, comp benefits are terrible. I played for approximately 4 to 5 hours and most of the time it was at the maximum coin-in level. When I went to the booth to try to get a comp slip for a meal they said I only accumulated $10.59.

Although the gimmicky era of Las Vegas Hotels has come to an end- due in part to the elegance of the City Center and Cosmopolitan- The NYNY is still a great place to stay. Here's why:

1. Entertainment- With a cirque show (Zumanity) an irish bar, a piano bar, coyote ugly, and a nightclub (ROK), you won't know how to split your time equally amongst the choices. Plus they have a roller coaster and arcade for the kids.

2. Deals- Sign up for a players card if you are going to gamble. The NYNY marketing team is very generous with their offers. I got 2 free nights, 50 dollars in free play on the slots, and 2 for 1 mgm show tickets on opening NCAA Tourney weekend with out having to lose the t-shirt off my back. The only stipulation is to get GOOD deals you must bet at least 15-30 dollars a hand consistently.
 
3. Location. Directly across from the MGM where you can take the monorail all the way to the North End of the strip. Also a 5 minute walk to the City Center. Also if you are renting a car, the parking garage here is conveniently located to the freeways for easy access to off the strip adventures.

4. ETC. Newly renovated rooms, (ask for one closest to the elevators) good sportsbook, tons of food options from italian to mexican to japanese at good prices, nice employees,  and a great atmosphere.

Other than a noisy roller coaster and unflattering gimmicky design, The NYNY is a great value.

I dont go to Vegas a lot. I havent been in all of the casinos\/ hotels. Of the ones i have seen I like this one best. 

We checked in for just one night. Valet great, bell service excellent, check in staff good. The room was good, very spacious. Our phone stopped working for some reason, not convenient. The pool was not too exciting here. 

The casino is great. Great variety of slots. Not many $5 tables, kinda sucked. The center bar plays the best music and is always packed with people in a good mood, feeling the vibe and having a blast. The food shops are so cute like a tiny nyc. 

Really like this place and would like to stay again!

The check-in was horrible. We waited 45 min only to see that the room was nothing like we booked. We asked for a non-smoking room with a king size bed, got a smoking room with two queen size beds! They said they will change it at 3 pm today which does not help because we are here for two nights only. So thanks for ruining the first one.

I venture to Vegas 2x a year, 1x with my family and 1x for a couples only trip. Because of my frequent visits(and gambling - just being honest), I have my rooms comped, as I  an MGM member. Even considering the free rooms, I won't be able to stay here again. My most recent trip, just a couple of months ago, I found the hotel dated, losing some of its charm, and no where near as friendly as it's been previously. The rooms are in need of repair and refreshment. The carpet is nasty and the bathroom had plumbing issues. 
I've been going to Vegas for 14 years straight, I've always loved the NyNy end of the strip, but that has come to a close. What's old is well, just old and what's new is where I'll now be. I wanted to update my review because I take YELP and the reviews seriously. If you're spending your money, you deserve to have the best and most accurate facts to make an informed decision.

Nice place, good overall customer service, especially with the Front Desk and Bell staff. 

We showed up around noon hoping for an early check in. We were offered one of their "Park Avenue" room upgrades for $15 extra per night, available immediately. 

Sold. 

Great little room on the 28th floor, king size bed, view of the strip. Nice. 

Avoid the room service menu, the food comes from the America restaurant (see my other review). You're better off walking (staggering) to the Il Fornaio cafe or something like that.

Great mix of folks here, too. Seemed like a healthy mix of couples, families, sluts and douchebags... you know, normal folks. 

If you're a monorail rider, keep in mind that you have to walk across the overpass and through the MGM. Not a big deal, but just something to keep in mind if you want easy access to the station. A 1-day, or even a 3-day pass will save you money on frequent cab rides.

Not a bad room for the price. Rooms were clean and the staff were friendly. Use your MLife for added incentives. The only downfall were the rooms were  a very long way from the Century elevators:rooms 2082\/81. Almost needed a tram for the distance. They did offer upgrades for $10\/night but since I was paying, I declined. I would stay here again.

I wish that I could give this hotel 0 stars not only did they ruin my honeymoon but they stole hundreds of dollars of us and refused to give us a refund when we checked out early. When we first got there we were surprised to find out there is a $100 a night charge just for using a debit card plus a resort fee. To even check in we were slammed with a $800 fee on top of the $1300 we already paid for the hotel. Our room was facing a wall even though we had booked a room facing the strip and our hair dryer didn't even work. There were no spa amenities offered to hotel guests like all the other hotels we visited. The women working the casino tables were extremely rude and talked badly towards customers literally handing them money. Worst hotel experience of my entire life I will never be staying here again and deterring anyone I know from doing so. Go stay at the ARIA or the Wynn its worth the money most beautiful hotels I have seen with lots of access to spas and other features for free and the staff is actually friendly. Thanks for ruining my honeymoon.

I stayed here for a long weekend Wednesday - Monday. I really liked this hotel. They had many different types of restaurants and the authenticity and real feel of different landmarks in NYC. 

I would definitely come back for another stay the hotel staff was friendly and the rooms were clean. The pool is nothing to write home about with the rollercoaster kinda ruining the environment. However, there are so many other hotels with pools you can go to during the day.

On my recent trip to Vegas, there were two pivotal songs on mental repeat: "Waking Up in Vegas" and "Empire State of Mind." Naturally, the latter came over me when I first strolled into NYNY. The hotel itself is well designed. Restaurant Row was my favorite part of the hotel. It's modeled after a NY city street, complete with a cobblestone path, manhole covers, bright lights, brick buildings, and cafes. You don't quite feel like you're really in NY but it makes for a cool setting when you're grabbing a bite or just passing through.

However, I didn't care much for the casino or the four elevators placed at opposite corners of the building. How chaotic! Each one corresponds to a specific set of rooms so you can't use them interchangeably, and since I didn't feel like waiting in line to ask the concierge I had to figure it out the hard way.

We came here for ZUMANITY, which was absolutely unbelievable. We opted for one of the couches in the front row, and I really do think it's the way to go. Why hold back, you're already in Vegas. Live a little!

The walkway leading to the show is dim and colored with lights to coordinate to the show. By time you get to your seats, you are already deep into the whole thing. They really succeed at making it a completely immersive experience (or at least as much as they're able to). There is a bar located right outside of the showroom doors and we got our drinks + 2 waters there (for $53)- so maybe you'll want to get drinks somewhere beforehand, but aside from that it was perfect. 

And of course, the casino is gorgeous and themed down to the smallest details, like New York City. I always make sure to walk through this place or stay for a few hours, if the time permits. There's really nothing else like it on the strip, so make sure it's on your list when you visit!

Very bad service by the valet guys. Came with my brother in law and his brother to go on the roller coaster came back in less than 15 min and of course accidents happen sometimes, got unlucky dropped my valet ticket sometime during the time I paid for the ride. Went up to the pick up area told the guy what had happen. At first I understand that it's their "rules and regulations" that you aren't the person on the contract of the rental car you will not be able to get the rental back until the original person is there to pick it up, etc. but the bald white guy that was currently helping me was just rude and the way he to as talking down to me was unnecessary. I was just trying to see if I could get the car back because the guy had taken my name down when he gave me the ticket or give them my boyfriends full name but the way he told me he wasn't able to isn't necessary. & to make a good example, he told me if someone else where to find my ticket on the floor and has given it to him in attempt to get a "free car" while knowing that is our rental car he would have given it to the total stranger instead. That was what pissed me off. I am a reasonable person but that guy was just plain disrespectful. Don't work in a field that you can't provide good service.

Not a bad place, there is no buffet here and the self parking here is a little weird because you have to stop and roll your window down and some guy waves you through. I stayed in a room near the roller coaster... don't do this. It's highly annoying and runs non-stop and nobody told me this. The staff, as in any MGM property, are always nice. The walls seemed a little thin as I could hear most of the conversation from the guys in the next room. The bathroom seemed tiny and a little grimy if you ask me. Not a bad place, but I stay in Vegas every other week and I could find a nicer room for less money else where on the strip.

I don't know what it is but I just really love this hotel\/casino...

We stayed here because I got a 20% off code, and we got our room relatively cheap. I must say that they had a pretty speedy maintenance service; we had an issue in our room and they quickly sent someone who fixed it within 5 minutes. Awesome. :) They staff was just overall pretty pleasant. 

The other reason that I like staying here is the theme. Even though I've never been there, I've always had a special place in my heart for NY. Therefore this place just makes me smile. :)

There also just a lot of things to do here. There's a variety of restaurants\/snacks\/shops and the arcade is great for when you have a family trip. 

Basically...I wish I could stay here every time. :)

Dated room.  Light out in bathroom, faucet head for cold water in sink broken and turns freely.  You must find the ever moving sweet spot to turn off.  Lack of hot water, warm at best.  Asked for repairs, no response as of yet.

Okay casino. Usually lively with younger people. I usually only come here for a couple of reasons: (1) get some NY pizza - they have some good stuff (or at least used to), (2) grab a beer at the Irish Pub, or (3) someone I came with wants to go see cheesy woman bartenders dance on the bar at Coyote Ugly. It is conveniently connected to MGM and Treasure Island via walkways. 

Bottom line: Go for the NYC pizza and Irish beer. The roller coaster is not bad too if you've never done it.

We just came back from a trip to Vegas and I've got to say that this was probably my worst experience yet. It seems like the staff is not happy because they act like they don't care for your business. From check in, to just the general staff. 

     Later my wife and I decided to go gamble downstairs and after spending about an hour at the table, not one single person approach us for a drink. I even started waving down waitresses who kept telling me that they did not service area I was in.This was two days in a row and we were drier than the desert itself. Worst part is I got up and lost my table to go get a drink and when I asked him for a common beer like Shocktop, the bartender told me they didn't serve it and I had to get it from another bar across the casino. He told me I'd find it under a certain sign but when I got to that sign everything was closed. From there we decided to no longer gamble in the hotel. There is definitely some other hotel that would appreciate our money. Later that night my daughter got a little sick and her throat was hurting, I called downstairs to see if they could send up some sugar so we can sweeten some hot tea that we made for her and and we explained it was for my daugter. They wanted to charge me $7 dollars to bring it up to me. I asked if I could come Down and get it and they tell me know that I would have to find some at either one of the coffee shops or a restaurant. Seriously? What kind of crap is that? The rooms were nice and spacious but even the beds were uncomfortable. I felt like that episode of I Love Lucy where Ricky and Lucy have to type themselves to the edge of the bed because the bed has a big dip in it. And the Internet is horrendous. I swear DialUp with AOL is faster than the Internet at this hotel and you're forced to pay $18 as a "resort fee". What a serious rip off, every time I tried downloading a file from work it would lag and I would have to start over. Just browsing the web was a joke.The only time I actually complained to anyone was about the gambling with no one approaching us for drinks. I actually had to tweet someone to get a response, but the only response I got was "I apologize and I'll forward this message to the manager". Whether they did it or not I have no clue. I would seriously suggest staying in a different hotel, some where that not only appreciates you as a guest, but treats you like one. Overall my experience with this hotel was horrible. I've been coming to Vegas for years, and this has got to be probably my worst stay ever.

After searching for good deals for weeks, the bf and I finally decided on NYNY due to the good reviews.  We were not disappointed.  =)

Parking was easy to find.  However, they have drivers roll down their windows before entering into the parking lot due to the possibility of inspection.  I didn't see any other hotel do this, so it was a bit of a puzzlement on what they were hoping to do by stopping cars, especially when it led to backup traffic.  

Check-In was simple.  We already had our rooms reserved, and we were able to get our Park Avenue room with a king-size bed and nonsmoking with no problems.  We also booked the room for Mon-Thurs, so this might have had an affect on which rooms we had.

I loved the consistency of the theme of NYNY through every part of the hotel.  When we visited the other hotels, I didn't see the consistency as much.  Then again, a them of "New York" should be more easily updated than with other hotels...

Room: 5 stars!  Clean clean clean clean clean.  My bf and I absolutely loved our room.  The a\/c worked (o thank goodness), the sheets were clean clean (which meant I didn't even do as thorough of a UV light cleaning like I would normally do :p  ), the furniture was stylish, and the entire floor was non-smoking.  I had previous experiences in other hotels where they didn't segregate the non-smoking from the smoking rooms very well, and I, with my sensitive senses, could not stomach the smell.  So, I was very happy with our room\/floor.  One of the negative things was the bathroom.  You REALLY have to lift up your legs to get into the tub\/shower.  There were more than a few times where I nearly tripped and fell into the tub because I was trying to get into it...  

By the way, the TV channels weren't that great.  Best thing I found on TV was probably PBS.  

No minifridge or microwave, but that's the same with the majority of the hotels on the strip.  We anticipated this and brought our own ice chest and filled it up with the ice from the ice machines on the floor.  It worked great.  =)

Didn't do room service, so can't comment on that.

Walls were fairly thick, as we didn't hear our neighbors.  Doors not as thick.  Then again, drunk patrons are hard to ignore when they're loud in general.

Lots of different foods on the first floor.  Hot dogs, deli sandwiches, ice cream, lots of drinks (it's Vegas), Italian restaurant, and American restaurant.  Probably lots of others I'm missing.

This was the first time the bf and I went to Vegas together, with each of us not having been back in a decade.  So, we were disappointed that the penny slots were not actually penny slots.  All machines accept either cards or dollar bills, but no coins.  So, we didn't really gamble much.  

Go to the America Restaurant.  We had the steak with crab legs dinner.  IT WAS AWESOME.  Steak cooked to the way we wanted it, the crab legs were huge, the baked potato was done right, and the appetizer of buffalo wings hit the spot.  And, the steak\/crab legs was only $15 per meal.  It was seriously one of the best meals we've ever had.  

One negative thing may be when we checked out and really saw all of the charges.  We were expecting the taxes and resort fees and the resort fee taxes, but it still made our hearts sink to see that those fees and taxes by themselves was basically an additional 20 a night on top of the room cost.  Still, it would have been the same in any hotel we stayed at on the strip.  For our 3 night stay, bill came out to around 200 dollars...

Overall, very likely that we'll stay here again.  Compared to other hotels\/casinos on the strip, NYNY was ventilated very well, and the smoke smell didn't really cling onto you.  Staff was courteous and helpful.  And, the room was awesome and better than I thought it would be.

We stay here often, because of the easy access from the 15 & the convenient strip location. Loved our big, luxurious jacuzzi suite! Great deal, & the small billing dispute was resolved promptly by Lori--thanks!
Nice hotel, great location. Rooms were clean.Staff was really nice here. Many food options here. Didn't go to pool but did notice a lot of kids at the pool so that was nice.

Great hotel..great rooms ..good restaurants and a roller coaster..
Not much of a gambler but the casino is pretty mid sized and has all the basics
The restaurants serve some great choices, from Mexican, Italian,Chinese,Pizzas etc.
The restaurant staff is very friendly and helpful.
Rooms are nice and big.Not very modern I must say.But clean and ample storage for clothes.
They have a roller coaster ride for $14 which is one helluva thrill.
Have stayed here twice and its always been a great experience.
We New Yorkers are biased.You cant really take a new yorker out of new york, can you? This hotel is home away from home..:-)

Clean rooms. Good selection of food & stores. Convenient location. Nice amenities. Quick elevators. Loved the Zumanity show. No complaints other than the smell of smoke (which is in all Vegas casinos) & lack of drink servers on the casino floor. Would stay again.

This review is about the arcade. I'm sure most people wouldn't  mind it, but I'm so disappointed that they changed everything. The arcade was a place my dad took me to since I was a kid, and we had so much fun. I went a couple times as an adult and remembered why I loved it so much so we started making it a regularly visited place again. Then we go today and they changed everything to a new system where you use a card for everything. I can definitely see the positives to this system but now they have removed several games including my favorite one. Also, we something was wrong with their system and we lost out on several hundred tickets. 

These things probably don't matter to a lot of people, but for me, because of the changes, this is no longer a place I will be visiting anymore. :( 

On another note, Nine Fine Irishmen is a pretty good restaurant.
Love staying here. It's a little smaller than most trip casinos but the ambience and amazing restaurants make up for it.

【WORST EXPERIENCE！！！】

This is the worst where I lived in Las Vegas hotel, front desk staff is so mean，he gave us to arrange the most remote corner rooms in the hotel, outside the window is a wall,blocked all of the view and there is no any light come in.That is Wednesday,all the way around the room should be nobody to live, the front desk guy is so mean to gave us this Disgusting room !Remind everybody, when you check-in the hotel,if room number is 383 or 384, do not live, go ask to change other rooms.

I spent Labor Day weekend with friends in Vegas and NYNY served as our homebase. The hotel itself is clean and well-attended with a nice variety of eateries, games, bars, and other standard casino fare. Self parking and valet are free. I opted to self park and parked on the roof of the garage and could see my ride from the room. Late checkout gives you an extra hour.

The burger joint, steakhouse, and Italian restaurant are particularly delicious with excellent service and the Irish pub and center bar are fun and lively spots. I didn't ride the roller coaster, but heard it was good enough to not feel ripped off.

The pool is nothing special, though cabanas are available to rent and I had the pleasure of relaxing by one. A flatscreen TV, fridge, outdoor fan, and plenty of lounge furniture made it an enjoyable intermission to the trip.

Visit the spa before booking, if possible. It's not the luxury you might expect from a hotel spa off the strip, but still nice.

Our room was situated in the New Yorker B tower, which overlooks the parking garage, roller coaster, and pool. The windows in this tower (and possibly others, too?) are quite small, allowing very little light into the room during the day. Lighting in the bathroom was also dim and water pressure somewhat weak. Our room had no fridge, but offered a safe and clock radio with iPod dock and a 40" flatscreen TV. Beds were moderately comfortable and extra pillows were provided. Free WiFi is available in all rooms.

The connecting bridge to Imperial Palace is handy as it leads to the free tram travelling to Mandalay Bay, home to House of Blues. 

Overall, this hotel is fine in terms of cleanliness and convenience. I'd stay here again, but if you're looking for Vegas extravagance where you're immersed in the hotel theme down to the detail, look elsewhere.

Room Tip: Some rooms are quite far from the elevators - if you have mobility limitations or fear the long walk an impossible chore after an evening of drink, request one close by!
Nice Room on the 26th floor. Easy access to the strip.

Ok just got back from a 3 night stay here. I had to come home and get on Yelp to voice my comments on some things at the hotel. First off I will say I like the hotel. The slots I will say don't pay off much but than again what casinos do pay out much. This was the 4 time I stayed here and 2 times when i brought my in-laws with us there rooms (accessable rooms) are always never ready till 5p. Still to this very day I still gripe about the resort fee. 33 bucks a day in addition to my already 97 dollar a night rooms. The one thing that really got me was now they are charging a valet fee of 18 bucks per day. OUCH !! If your a guest of the hotel why isn't it already part of the so called resort fee ?? I think it's just another way of getting more money out of us. Man I paid near 900 bucks for 2 Madison room 3 nights each.. Man I may have to start looking into VROB to get a condo to rent the next time I go to Las Vegas.

My review is for the casino level since i haven't stayed at this hotel.  The casino is lively with go go dancers, frozen alcoholic beverage stand served in those fun bong shaped contraptions.  I seem to have good luck here on the penny slots which i love!

I am staying in this hotel for the next three nights (Feb 7-10, 2017) and I am already VERY unhappy. At check-in, I was offered a $15 upgrade from the Park Ave to the Madison Ave room. The desk clerk was very sweet and was not a problem at all. However, she did say the Madison Ave rooms were "renovated."  I normally wouldn't pay for an upgrade, but I do like new rooms so I confirmed, "the Madison rooms have been renovated?," to which she replied yes. Upon getting to my room, it is quite dated. Beyond that, the furnishings are rather beaten up (dings on all corners and along some edges), chairs are dingy and have a few small stains, I had trouble opening one of the curtains because the rail is apparently damaged, there are many scuffs and what may be patches or smoke stains on the wallpaper, and the bathroom looks 20 years old if a day. I called to ask if there are other rooms in this class more recently renovated, and I was told by a polite agent that when they sold me on a "renovated" room, they meant that it is only more recently renovated than the other room I had booked. He initially said "it's been a couple of years," to which I replied that it has CLEARLY been considerably longer than that, then listed some of the signs of age I noted above. Later in the conversation, he said it had been "about five years or so" (I doubt that's true, from the look of the room), and told me that the only thing they could offer would be to allow me to downgrade and check into the lower room type. I said I am unwilling to do that without seeing it first, and he said they would reserve a key for me at the desk for one-time entry into the other room. 

I'm an easy traveler. Read any of my other reviews - I don't review often, and when I do it is with little complaint. But this is ridiculous. I was offered an upgrade that I did not ask for, FOR A FEE, and I was told it was "renovated." I shouldn't then walk into a room that NEEDS RENOVATED, but happened to have been renovated apparently a decade or more ago. Almost every hotel room in the country more than ten years old would apparently qualify as "renovated" by this hotel's standards. If it's ever BEEN renovated, they apparently consider it suitable to say it is renovated for purposes of getting an upgrade fee. The thing is, but for their deceptive practices, it's not that I'm all that unhappy with the room. I've stayed in much better, but I've stayed in worse and I felt I got a good deal when I booked. I would be writing a positive review in a few days, no doubt, had I not been told I was getting something that I am not (for a fee, offered to me without my request for an upgrade). 

At the very least, when I called to inquire initially I feel my upgrade fee should have been refunded and I should not be inconvenienced by having to look at another room to see if it's too crappy for me to stay in. At this point, this hotel should be offering me a TRUE upgrade, free of charge. If that doesn't happen, I will definitely not be staying here, nor will I spend a dime in this casino or at any of its restaurants or events. There is plenty to do in Vegas without NYNY.

This is the first time we have stayed here. We checked in around 9:00ish at night and the check in took a bit. Our room was nice, we decided to get the room with the jacuzzi tub. The room felt comfortable. We enjoyed our stay here. The only down fall is now they charge their guests for parking. It is $10 a day and your able to park at any Mlife related hotels but I just thought wow. I would recommend this hotel, I liked it. Wished we could've stayed longer.

Great hotel, great price. This one is fairly cheap and has a great feel to it. I love the New York theme. 

Check in and out was quick and easy. When we checked in we left our bags with the bell hop since we arrived before 3:00. At 1:00 our room was ready, and the bell hop brought our bags up quickly. 

The room was nice. We had the Park Avenue room on the 29th floor. It was clean and the bed was pretty comfortable. Not rock hard but not super plush either. I though the decor was simple but nice. It wasn't over the top, but I liked it. It wasn't extremely plain. 

There's a lot to do in the hotel and around the area. The roller coaster is fun but at times can be painful. There's a lot of good food in the New York hotel, too. Although, I will say skip the starbucks. We got a tall coffee, one of the protein boxes, and a small sandwich and it was $17!!! And then they wanted to charge 50 cents for a cup of water. There's other places to get a quick bite in the hotel, but it was very early when we went and it was the only thing open. Just avoid it. 

The only thing I really didn't like about the pool is that it was small. Like really small. Other hotels have multiple pools and they are large! But this one was one tiny bean shaped pool that was only 4.5 feet deep. That part of the hotel could use some improvement, but other than that it's a good place to stay.

I stayed here overnight as a flight home wasn't available until the next morning.

With that, this review is specifically about the front desk person and my room.  I didn't utilize any of the many restaurants, food areas, games, etc....

The front desk person was incredibly nice and super understanding when I explained I wasn't there for the "Vegas" experience.  I just wanted a quiet (quiet enough) room.  

The room I was in overlooked the roller coaster which was fine.  I heard it and the screams of people for a while.  The alarm clock has a nice sound effect feature.  I turned up the ocean waves to block out the outside noise and all was well.  Otherwise it was a standard room.  It was clean, the bed was comfy and the shower was fine.  

Overall, I had an "a-ok" stop over on my way home.

First time in Vegas. Stayed here. Casino was okay. Food in the hotel is waay over priced. Drinks are even worse. I paid $14 for the sorriest bloody mary at Il Fornaio after the bartender said they had good ones. It was served to me in a plastic cup though I wasnt at the pool. Was gambling for hours and only got teo drinks despite being a good tipper.  Went with girlfriend for her birthday and valentines day. Asked if it was possible to upgrade room for these reasons. Got a $200 increase in cost and a view of a brick wall about 5 feet from the window and the roof out the other window. Also, one night the building alarm sounded for about half an hour them finally told us " everything was ok".  Overall a lackluster experience. Not sure if I can but will post a pic of the bloody. Sooooo disappointing.
Loved this place and the vibe. The New York theme is charming. A great place for my first trip to Vegas. It's also connected to the MGM which is nice.

Stayed here for 3 nights when I was in Vegas to get married. The rates were awesome in December and since we planned on venturing off the strip quite a bit, it had great access to the interstate without having to drive on barely any of Las Vegas Blvd. 

We did not gamble at all, so I have nothing to say about the casino, but it seemed much more open and airy than a lot of the other ones we walked through. 

All the staff I encountered were very nice and pleasant. The room we had was very clean and had a nice TV and a great view of the strip and the roller coaster. 

I haven't stayed at any other hotel\/casinos to compare it to, but there was nothing I could really complain about. 

The only thing I noted about the other hotel\/casinos on the strip that I may have liked better was that they had more "cheaper" food options.

Hotel is a mini new york for sure! I stayed here post 9-11 and wondered how they removed the twin towers part of the hotel so quickly and found out they were never apart of the hotel to begin with, weird! This hotel has some cute features like for their elevators being named after famous buildings like empire state, and chrysler building. I stayed in a suite and it was nice, but it wasn't that nice since it was on the bottom floor! uhh no view except for a piece of railroad track of the roller coaster! Luckily the roller coaster would only operate mid-morning at 11ish and stop running around 7 or 8 so it wasn't a problem. Location wise this hotel is okay, but its more toward the beginning of the strip.  But the whole look of the hotel of Manhattan all bundled up is a must see!
